template.description: This process group contains examples of transformations using the Jolt Transformation Language
template.name: Group of Jolt Examples

processGroups.comments: This process group contains a collection of examples of JSON-to-JSON transformations using the Jolt transformation language

labels.label: Add a field to each element of the array
One-to-One json transformation - If you are new to Jolt then you should review this process group first
This process group demonstrates grabbing the name of a field and using it as a value in the JSON output
Splits one array into 2 arrays based on value of some field

This is setup as an API. Endpoint for local nifi is below: ------------------------------------------------ localhost:8092/nifi ------------------------------------------------ The port number can be changed in the properties tab of the configuation of the processor

This processor uses Jolt to do JSON-to-JSON transformations ------------------------------------------- Transformations can be tested within the Canvas by >> Double-click processor >> Look at bottom left corner of new screen >> Click Advanced button
The HttpContextMap chosen for this processor needs to be the same HttpContextMap chosen for the HandleHttpRequest processor
This replaces the body of the flowfile with the JSON text to transform
** Note ** - The values on the left side of the colons (otherwise known as keys) in the Jolt spec must match the structure of the incoming data

processGroups.comments: This process group shows demonstrates grabbing the name of a field and using it as a value in the JSON output

labels.label: This processor uses Jolt to do JSON-to-JSON transformations ------------------------------------------- Transformations can be tested within the Canvas by >> Double-click processor >> Look at bottom left corner of new screen >> Click Advanced button
This replaces the body of the flowfile with the JSON text to transform

This is setup as an API. Endpoint for local nifi is below: ------------------------------------------------ localhost:8090/nifi ------------------------------------------------ The port number can be changed in the properties tab of the configuation of the processor
The HttpContextMap chosen for this processor needs to be the same HttpContextMap chosen for the HandleHttpRequest processor

The processor to the right of this label, aptly named JoltTransformJSON, uses the Jolt spec seen in the section below ----- [ { "operation": "shift", "spec": { "cat": { "0": { "*": { "$": "cat-attributes" } } } } } ] ----- This spec takes the names of the keys in the input JSON and places them as values within the outgoing array ----- Explanation: The left side (key side) of the spec refers to how and what to map. 1. "cat" is considered the root element to look for 2. "0" states to only look for values in the 0th index >> of the array named in the previous step ("cat") 3 "*" states to do the upcoming mapping to every >> element in the array >> the elements in this case contain key/value pairs 4. Within the key/value pair statement, >>>> a. "$" states that the name of the current key >>>>>> should be grabbed and used as the target value >>>> b. "cat-attributes" states that the value previously >>>>>> grabbed (target value) should be put into an >>>>>> array with the name of "cat-attributes"

processGroups.name: Jolt Grab name of field

labels.label: This replaces the body of the flowfile with some predefined JSON text
The HttpContextMap chosen for this processor needs to be the same HttpContextMap chosen for the HandleHttpRequest processor

The green label below shows the Jolt spec that allows mapping to take place - The top section of the green label is the spec - The bottom sections of the green label give an explanation of what the spec does

This is setup as an API. Endpoint for local nifi is below: ------------------------------------------------ localhost:8090/nifi ------------------------------------------------ The port number can be changed in the properties tab of the configuation of the processor

This processor uses Jolt to do JSON-to-JSON transformations ------------------------------------------- Transformations can be tested within the Canvas by >> Double-click processor >> Look at bottom left corner of new screen >> Click Advanced button
The HttpContextMap chosen for this processor needs to be the same HttpContextMap chosen for the HandleHttpRequest processor

This is setup as an API. Endpoint for local nifi is below: ------------------------------------------------ localhost:8091/nifi ------------------------------------------------ The port number can be changed in the properties tab of the configuation of the processor
This replaces the body of the flowfile with the JSON text to transform

The difference between the Jolt spec in this processor and the Jolt spec in Process Group Jolt Transformation 1-to-1 is the addition of @(1,type) where feline once was - "feline[&1].color" states: 1. make an array whose root key is feline 2. make a field with the name "color" in >>the "feline" array - @(1,type)[&1].color states: 1. make an array whose root element name >> a. is the value at the key named type >> b. and look for that element 1 level up >>>> from where this statement is c. ensure the root key(s) in an array

This processor uses Jolt to do JSON-to-JSON transformations ------------------------------------------- Transformations can be tested within the Canvas by >> Double-click processor >> Look at bottom left corner of new screen >> Click Advanced button

processGroups.name: Jolt Transformation one (1) array to two (2) arrays
Jolt Transformation Examples

versionControlInformation.flowDescription: This process group contains Jolt Transformation examples
